title: Why League should be balanced for challenger/master
body:
Imagine you join a chess League. You start playing and win some games. You get up to maybe their gold division. Now, you run into some complications competing. People in gold are utilizing their complex pieces like Knights and Bishops way better than you, while are more use to linear tactics like your Rook(Castles) and Pawn Cheese. On top of that, the chess from gold and up has timed moves.

Would it be fair, for you to demand that Knights and Bishops be removed, replaced with linear Rooks(Castles), and the timers to be removed? Just because you cannot think on your feet, make moves quickly and utilize complex pieces. Doesn't mean Master tier chess players should remove Knights and Bishops and stop castling, remove the timers and have a slow and linear game. Rather, you should have to learn to play chess better, faster and with more skill in order to compete with them.

This is a thoughtline I never understood. "We should balance the game for the majority." If you balance for a majority of people, who are low skill level, you set the bar low. If you start removing all of the complex mechanics from the game and fast moving twitchy champions, and replacing their kits with slow linear ones. You are shitting on top tier play, for the sake of what? Making sure low tier plays get a participation trophy?

If the game was balanced around the most middle ground in League, Silver, that means any player above silver has an imbalanced game, and in order to have a balanced game they have to play the game worse. If you balance and design the game around Challenger/Master tier play however, that means when the game is played at it's most optimum, it is balanced. And low tier players will eventually adapt and to the best of their ability try to mimic them, achieving 'balance' by getting better at the game.

Currently, League tries to balance for everyone, the problem with this is, it means it is balanced for nobody.

Yi is OP until gold then worthless above. Riven is worthless below gold then OP in Diamond-Challenger. This is no way to balance a game or a sport.

So before you condemn complex pieces, advanced strategies and timers. Think to yourself. "Maybe I just need to get better at chess. Instead of trying to tear master chess players down to the level of my Rook and Pawn cheese." Because the moment Riot balances the game AND designs for top tier play? Every champion becomes a viable pick when played to an optimum level.

I don't think the chess analogy really fits, in chess both sides are set up as equal with pieces that can only move a finite number of turns thus the game is inherently balanced between players simply because they have the same options as one another. There's also lesser known rules like the En passant that the non chess players probably wouldn't know because it is extremely situational. If you removed the queen or knight from chess then you're not really balancing the game for even lower play at all, you're just removing aspects of it which is why I don't think this analogy makes sense.

Besides I reckon you'd only tell the good from the bad chess players by how they use their pawns at the start of each game.  Novice chess players tend to focus too much on their queen.

Well thought out reasoning, I enjoy the chess analogy, which is rather fitting for the subject matter.

The problem with the chess analogy is simple:

Chess is a game where both sides start with equal power and a perfectly mirrored board with almost perfectly symmetrical placement (both white and black face off mirrored, and the left/right sides for each are symmetrical outside of the Queen/King).

________________________
If you want a further explanation, lets take the example of the Knight the OP used. A newer or less strategic player might not utilize their Knights and might opt for a more linear style of play, but that doesnt mean that they are at an inherent disadvantage. Their disadvantage is their skill, knowledge, and quick analysis. 

Sure you can take away Knights or Bishops in the game to balance for linear thinkers, but by the mirrored style of game, its the same advantage or disadvantage to both players. At the end of the day, its the more skilled player in the game who wins. 

However, League's balance is inherently thrown off by the Champions. There is no perfectly equal matchup. And here lies the problem - a Challenger player might have trouble winning consistently with Yi, even if they are just as mechanically proficient as another Challenger player who plays Riven, because (as an example) A) people react faster to Yi at that level and B) they know how to animation cancel on Riven to push her to her potential limit. However, the same doesnt go in Bronze - a Bronze Yi player might have more success than a Bronze Riven, because A) people miss or mistime their CC more in Bronze and B) Bronze Rivens dont animation cancel as proficiently. 

When you say things like, "They should balance around Challenger," does that mean they should buff Yi so he is better in Challenger but completely steamrolls the game in every tier below that?

Lol should have seen the StarCraft 2 forums 1-2 years after it was released.
what happened?

People actually complained about things like proxy rax being OP. 

What that means is that a Terran player would build his Tier 1 (basic) combat unit production building outside of the opponent's base and spam Marines (weakest, although bread&butter, Terran unit) out of it. 

Protoss was effectively immune to this due to how much stronger Zealots (weakest protoss)/Stalkers (bread&butter protoss) are than Marines. 

Zerg could get Zerglings (weakest unit in the game, but 2 per production) out far, far, far earlier than anyone else could get units out, thus had no excuse. 6 pool "zerg rush" is a meme for a reason. 

___________

The only way you could get proxy rax cheesed is if you didn't scout, which is the simple act of sending a worker out of your base to look around (simple), find the enemy base spawn location (depending on map; simple), and get intel on the build order they're committing to so you can prepare and counter (somewhat complicated, but not required to counter proxy rax).

__________

P.S. Proxy rax was effectively not viable. 100% of people would not be set back by it anywhere above silver. Most people would be able to kill the Marines and find/destroy the rax even if they did not scout it.

They can't. It would be completely absurd to try.

I think you are miss representing the situation by cherry picking your example. The actual question is, should pawn cheese be something that can be done to success in high Elo, given that it is then supported by knights and bishops? 

If your answer is, "pawn cheese should not be viable in high elo" than the high elo game becomes  "castle into knights and bishops." Essentially the game becomes more poor for high Elo because the range of viable options is smaller. 

Whereas a better situation is that pawn cheese is viable in high elo, given that it is supported (in high elo) or that it supports knights/bishop play. This gives the high elo player more depth in the game because he can open castle into knight/bishop, or pawn cheese into knight/bishop, or knight/bishop into pawn cheese or any of the other options. 

In your example, high elo is playing pure knight/bishop, whereas low elo is playing pure pawn cheese. The transition from low to high elo is simple to learn: understand knight/bishop, learn to answer pawn cheese, advance. 

whereas the better situation is for low elo players to play simple pawn cheese AND crappy knight/bishop, and high elo players to play transitional/supported pawn cheese AND advanced knight/bishop. This gives both types of players a richer game.
